thread.title: Digital Heroes 2015: Vote for your Volunteer winner from these nominees now

author: Mirror.co.uk
title: Digital Heroes 2015: Vote for your Volunteer winner from these nominees now
text:
Earlier this year, we asked you to put forward your local digital heroes so they can be nominated for this year's awards.
The projects have finally been shortlisted - and now we're asking you to nominate a project to win £10,000 and the title of TalkTalk Digital Hero 2015.
One category - the Volunteer Award - was for an individual dedicating time and effort to their local community through volunteering.
It could be someone who collects donations by an app on their iPhone or it could be someone who’s designed the app.
Volunteer nominees 2015 Caitlin Dean - Hyperemesis Improvement Movement Caitlin Dean pioneered the Pregnancy Sickness Support volunteer network which provides one-to-one support for women suffering extreme illness during pregnancy.
Hyperemesis Gravidarum can be a terribly isolating condition leading to poor maternal mental health and a host of other complications.
Thanks to digital technologies and platforms, women no longer have to suffer the condition alone as they can receive peer support from her network of experienced volunteers around the UK.
Suzannah Yianni - Age UK Enfield In an increasingly digital world many of society’s most vulnerable older people are becoming more and more isolated due to their lack of confidence, knowledge and skills around using computers.
Age UK Enfield’s Trans IT project brings younger and older people together by training sixth form students to volunteer and teach older people the IT skills they need to stay connected to the world we all now take for granted.
As well as the impact on the older person’s life, the younger volunteers have the opportunity to develop new skills.
Helen McCabe - Community Get Better Known Community Get Better Known provides young volunteers with training and hands-on experience in a work environment.
Volunteers work alongside other volunteers, learning together in a positive environment to be more engaged in their community.
Results of their work gives local voluntary groups (who cannot access website development and marketing due to cost) a low-cost website and lots of free marketing.
Helen has helped charities supporting children with autism; families struggling financially and many others.
Melanie Kopik - Digital Connectors Melanie is a Get Connected Digital Connector . Volunteering from her own home in Folkestone she gives around three hours of their time per week to respond to young people in crisis and in need of help with issues such as bullying, exam stress, self-harm and suicide.
Like Melanie the Digital Connector team are using helpline technology to support thousands of children and young people a year via their fastest growing channel: webchat.
Chantel Samson - MPower People CIC Chantel Samson is responsible for Mpower People CIC’s Community Outreach service, giving support to improve digital inclusion and enhance self-esteem and confidence.
Chantel is a strong community member working with disabled learners, in community centres in disadvantaged communities, with vulnerable people, Armed Forces Veterans, homeless people or those living in sheltered or supported accommodation or at risk of losing their tenancies and people with Mental Health issues.
Chantel has supported over 300 people to improve their IT skills in the last 6 months.
Cast your vote here Keep up to date with the latest information on the TalkTalk Digital Heroes Awards via the @TalkTalkComms Twitter feed or by searching #digitalheroes .
Read more about the awards on the TalkTalk blog or on Facebook.
Have your say in our new comments section below
DailyMirror
